Title.evidence: This randomised controlled trial evaluates the effectiveness of combined cup and stem anteversion in total hip arthroplasty (THA) using computer navigation to address abnormal femoral anteversion.

Trial_Design.evidence: 47 patients with abnormal femoral anteversion undergoing THA were randomised.

Participants.evidence: Conducted at a single orthopedic center, 47 patients with abnormal femoral anteversion undergoing THA were randomised. Eligibility criteria included adults with a clinical indication for THA.

Intervention.evidence: The intervention group used computer navigation for combined anteversion, while the control group relied on the surgeon's estimation.

Objective.evidence: This randomised controlled trial evaluates the effectiveness of combined cup and stem anteversion in total hip arthroplasty (THA) using computer navigation to address abnormal femoral anteversion.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the precision and bias of stem anteversion, assessed postoperatively via CT scans over a 6-month period.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed using sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: 47 patients were randomised, with 24 in the intervention group and 23 in the control group.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The navigation group demonstrated a precision of 4.8° and a bias of 0.2°, while the control group showed a precision of 16.8° and a bias of 0.2°.

Harms.evidence: No adverse events were reported in either group.
